sp.p: Gods mee you must not inquire how shee does, thats priuy counsell, fie, ther's manners indeed.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Pray you pardon my inciuility, I was som-what bould with you, but beleeue me Ile neuer be so sawcy to aske you how you do againe, as long as I liue la.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Square chub, what sullene black is that.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p:
A tassell that hangs at my purse strings, hee dogs mee and I giue him scraps and pay for his ordinary, feede him, hee liquors himselfe in the iuice of my bounty, and when hee hath suckt vp strength of spirit he squeaseth it in my owne face, when I haue refind and sharp'd his wits with good food, hee cuts my
fingers, and breakes iests vpon me, I beare them, and beate him: but by this light the dull eyed thinks he dos wel, dos very well, and but that hee and I are of two faithes— I fill my belly, and feeds his braine, I could find in my heart to hug him, to hug him.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Pree-thee perswade him to assume spirit and salute vs.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Lampatho, Lampatho, art out of countenance, for witts sake salute these beauties, how doost like them?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Vds fut, I can liken them to nothing, but great mens great horse vpon great dayes, whose tailes are trust vp in silke and siluer.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: To them man, salute them.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Blesse you faire Ladies, God make you all his seruants.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: God make you all his seruants.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Hee is holpen well had need of you, for bee it spoken without prophanisme hee hath more in this traine, I feare mee you ha more seruants then he, I am sure the Diuill is an Angell of darkenesse.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I but those are Angels of light.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Light Angels, pree-thee leaue them, with-draw a little and heare a Sonnet pree-thee, heare a Sonnet.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Made of Albanos widdow that was, and Mounsieur Lauerdures wife that must be.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Come leaue his lips and command some liquor, if you haue no Bottle-Ale, command some Claret-wine and Bourrage, for that's my predominate humor sleeke billid Bacchus, lets fill thy guttes.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay heare it, and rellish it iuditiously.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I do rellish it most iuditially. Quad. drinkes.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Adored excellence, delicious sweet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Delicious sweete good, very good.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: If thou canst taste the purer iuice of loue.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: If thou canst taste the purer iuice, good still, good still.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I doe rellish it, it tastes sweete.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Is not the metaphor good, ist not well followed?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Passing good, very pleasing.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Ist not sweete.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Let me see't Ile make it sweete,
Ile soake it in the iuice of Helicon.
Bir Lady, passing sweete, good, passing sweete.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: You wrong my Muse.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: The Irish flux vpon thy Muse, thy whorish Muse,
Heere is no place for her loose brothelry,
We will not deale with her, goe, away, away,

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Ile be reueng'd.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: How pree-thee in a play? come, come, be sosiable
In priuate seuerance from societie,
Here leapes a vaine of bloud inflam'd with loue,
Mounting to pleasure, all adict to mirth,
thoult read a Satyre or a Sonnet now,
Clagging their ayery humor with—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Lamp oyle, watch Candles, Rug-gownes & small iuice,
Thin commons, foure a clock rising, I renounce you all,
Now may I ternally abandon meat
Rust fustie you which most imbrac'd disuse,
You a made me an Asse, thus shapt my lot,
I am a meere Scholler, that is a meere sot.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Come then Lampe, ile powre fresh Oyle into thee,
Apply thy spirit that it may nimbly turne,
Vnto the habit, fashion of the age,
Ile make thee man the Scholler, inable thy behauiour,
Apt for the intertaine of any presence:
Ile turne thee gallant, first thou shalt haue a Mistresse,
How is thy spirit rais'd to yonder beauty?
She with the sanguine cheeke, the dimpled chinne,
The pretty amorous smile that clips her lips,
And dallyes bought her cheeke—
Shee with the speaking eye,
That castes out beames as ardent as those flakes,
Which sing'd the world by rash braind Phaeton,
She with the lip, O lips! she for whose sake,
A man could finde in his heart to in-hell himselfe,
There's more Philosophy, more theoremes,
More demonstrations, all inuincible,
More cleare diuinity drawne on her cheeke,
Then in all volumes tedious paraphase,
Of musty eld, O who would staggering doubt,
The soules eternity, seeing it hath
Of heauenly beauty, but to case it vp,
Who would distrust a supreame existence,
Able to confound when it can create,
Such heauen on earth able to intrance,
Amaze: O I 'tis prouidence, not chance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now by the front of Ioue me thinks her eye
Shootes more spirit in me, O beautie feminine!
How powerfull art thou, what deepe magick lyes
Within the circle of thy speaking eyes.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why now could I eate thee, thou doost please mine appetite, I can disist thee, God made thee a good foole, and happy and ignorant, and amarous, and riche and fraile, and a Satyrist, and an Essayest, and sleepy, and proud, and indeed a foole and then thou shalt bee sure of all these. Doe but scorne her shee is thine owne, accost her carelesly, and her eye promiseth shee will be bound to the good abbearing.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Now sister Meletza doost marke their craft, some straggling thoughts transport thy attentiuenesse from his discourse, wast Iacomos or our brothers plot?

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.p: Both, both, sweete Lady, my Page heard all, we mette the roague, so like Albano, I beat the roague.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I but when you were gone the roague beat me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Now take my counsell, listen.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: A pretty youth, a pretty well shapt youth, a good leg, a very good eye, a sweete ingenious face, and I warrant a good witte, nay which is more, if hee bee poore I assure my soule hee is chaste and honest, good faith I fancy, I fancie him, I and I may chance, well Ile thinke the rest.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I say bee carelesse still, court her without complement take spirit.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.l: Wert not a pleasing ieast for me to cloath
Another rascall like Albano, say
And rumor him return'd without all deceit,
Would not beget errors most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Meletza bella belletza, Madonna, bella bella genteletza pree-thee kisse this initiated gallant.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: How would it please you I should respect yee.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: As any thing, What you will as nothing.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: As nothing, how will you valew my loue.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Why iust as you respect me, as nothing, for out of nothing, nothing is bred, so nothing shall not beget any-thing, any-thing bring nothing, nothing bring any-thing, any-thing & nothing shal be What you will, my speach mounting to the valieu of my selfe which is.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: What sweete—

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Your nothing light as your selfe scencelesse as your sex, and iust as you would ha me, nothing.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Your wit skips a morisco, but by the brightest spangle of my tier, I vouchafe you intire vnaffected fauor, were this gentle spirit be not proud.
sp.l: Beleeue it youth slow speech, swift loue doth often shrowd.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: My soul's intranc'd your fauor doth transport,
My scence past scence, by your adored graces,
I doat, am rapt.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: Nay if you fall to passion and past scence,
My breasts no harbor for your loue, go packe, hence.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Vds fut thou gull, thou inkie scholler, ha, thou whoreson fop,
Wilt not thou clappe into our fashion'd gallantry,
Couldst not be proud and skornfull, loofe and vaine
Gods my hearts obiect, what a plague is this:
My soul's intraunc'd, fut couldst not clip and kisse,
My soul's intraunc'd, ten thousand crownes at least
Lost lost, my soul's intraunc'd, loues life O beast!

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Celia open, open Celia, I would enter, open Celia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Celia, open, open Celia, I would enter open Celia.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: What Celia let in thy husband Albano what Celia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What Celia let in thy husband Albano what Celia

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Vds f, f, f, fut let Albano enter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Vds f, f, f, fut let Albano enter.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Sweete breast you ha playd the wag yfaith.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Beleeue it sweete not I.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Come you haue attired some fiddler like Albano to fright the perfumer, ther's the iest.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Good fortunes to our sister.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: And a speedy marriage.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.p: Then we must wish her no good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: For shame, for shame straight cleere your house; sweepe out this dust, fling out this trash, returne to modesty your husband I say your husband Albano that was supposd drownd is return'd I and at the dore.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Ha ha, my husband, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.p: Laugh you, shameles? laugh you?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come, come, your plots discouerd, good faith kinsmen I am no skold: to shape a Perfumer like my husband, O sweete iest.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Last hopes all knowne.

sp.speaker: Celi
sp.p: For pennance of your fault will you maintaine a iest now, my loue hath tired some fiddler like Albano, like the Perfumer.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Not I by blessednesse not I.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come tis true, do but support the iest and you shal surfet, with laughter.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Faith we condiscend, twill not be crosd I see,
Marriage and hanging go by destiny.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: B, b, b, bar out Albano, O Adulterous impudent.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: B, b, b, bar out Albano, O thou matchlesse g, g, g, gigglet.

div.stage: Enter Albano and Francisco.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Let them in, let them in, now, now, now obserue, obserue, look, look, look.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: That sames a fiddler, shapt like thee, feare naught, bee confident thou shalt know the iest heereafter, be confident; feare naught, blush not, stand firme.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p:
Now brothers, now gallants, now sisters now call a Perfumer a gutter-maister, bar mee my house, beate mee: baffle
me, skoffe me, deride mee, ha that I were a young man againe, by the mas I would ha you all by the eares, by the mas law; I am Francisco Soranza am I not gigglet: strumpet, cutters, swaggerers, brothell haunters, I am Francisco, O god, O slaues, O dogges, dogges, curres.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: No sir pray you pardon vs, we confesse you are not Francisco nor a Perfumer, but euen.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: But euen Albano.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: But euen a fiddler, a miniken tickler, a pum, pum.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A scraper, scraper.
Art not asham'd before Albanos face,
To clip his spouze, O shamlesse impudent!

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Well said perfumer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: A fiddler a scraper, a miniken tickler, a pum, a pum, euen now a Perfumer, now a fiddler, I will be euen What you will, do, do do, k, k, k, kisse my wife be, be, be, be, fore.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why would'st haue him kisse her behind?

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Before my owne f, f, f, face.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Well done fiddler.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Ile f, f, fiddle yee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Dost f, f, floute mee.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Dost m, m, m, mock me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ile to the Duke Ile p, p, p, paste vp infamies on euery post.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Twas rarely, rarely done, away, away. Exit Francisco.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Ile f, f, follow, though I st, st, st, stut, ile stumble to the Duke in p, p, plaine language, I pray you vse my wife well, good faith shee was a kinde soule and an honest woman once, I was her husband and was call'd Albano before I was drown'd, but now after my resurrection I an I know not what indeede brothers, and indeed sisters and in deed wife I am: What you will, do'st thou laugh, dost thou ge, ge, ge, gerne; a p, p, p, perfumer a fiddler, a Diabalo, matre de Dios, Ile f, f, f, firk you by the Lord now, now I will. Exit Albano.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Ha ha tis a good roague, a good roague.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A good roague ha, I know him not.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: No good sweete loue come come dissemble not,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Nay if you dread nothing happy be my lot
Come Via sest, come faire cheekes, come lets dance,
The sweetes of loue is amorous dalliance.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: All friends, all happy friends, my vaines are light,

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: Thy praiers are now god send it quickly night.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: And then come morning.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: I thats the hopefull day.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I there thou hitst it.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Pray God he hit it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Play.

div.stage: The Daunce.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: They say ther's reuells and a Play at Court.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A Play to night?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: I tis this gallants wit,

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Ist good ist good?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I feare twill hardly hit.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I like thy feare, wel, twil haue better chance,
Ther's naught more hatefull then ranck ignorance.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come gallants the table spread will you to dinner?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Yes first a maine at dice and then weele eate.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truely the best wittes haue the bad'st fortune at dice still.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Whole Play, whole play.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not I, in truth I haue still exceeding bad fortune at dice.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.l: Come shall we in, infayth thou art suddaine sad,
Dost feare the shaddow of my long dead Lord.

sp.speaker: Lauer,
sp.l: Shaddow ha I cannot tel
Time tryeth all things well. wel, well.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Would I were time then, I thought twas for some thing that the old fornicator was bald behinde; go passe on passe on.

div.head: SCAE. 1.
div.stage: The Curtaines are drawne by a Page, and Celia and Lauerdure, Quadratus, and Lyzabetta, Lampatho and Meletza Simplicius, and Lucea displayed sitting at Dinner. The Song is sung, during which a Page whispers with Simplicius.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Feede and be fat my fayre Calipolis,
Riuo heer's good iuice, fresh Burrage boy?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I commend, commend my selfe to yee Lady.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: In troth Sir you dwell farre from neighbours that are inforc'd to commend your selfe.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Why Simplicius, whether now man, for good fashions sake stirre not, fit still, sit still.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I must needs rise, much good do it you.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Doost thou thinke thy rising will do them much good, sit still, sit still, carue me of that good Melletza: fill Bacchus fill.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I must needs bee gone, and youle come to my Chamber to morrow morning, Ile send you a hundred crownes.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: In the name of Prosperitie, what tide of happinesse so suddeinly is flou'd vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ile keepe a horse and foure boyes with grace of fortune now.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Now then ifaith get vp and ride.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And I do not? Ile thwack a Ierkin till he groane againe with Gold lace: let mee see, what should I desire of God, mary a Cloake linde with rich Taffata, white Sattin sute, and my gilt Rapier from pawne, nay shee shall giue me a Chaine of Pearle that shall pay for all, good boy, good Sinior, good boye, good Sinior.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p:
Why now, thou speaketh in the most imbrac'd fashion that our time hugges, no sooner a good fortune, or a fresh sute falles vpon a fellow that would ha beene guld to ha shou'd into your society, but and he met you he fronts you with a faint eye, throwes a squint glaunce ouer a wried shoulder and cryes
twixt the teeth, as very parcimonious of breath, good boy, good Sinior, good boy, good Sinior death: I will search the life bloud of your hopes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And a fresh Pearle-colour silke stocking o IIII, Ile goe to the halfe crowne ordinary euery meale, Ile haue my Iuory boxe of Tobacco, Ile conuerse with none but Counts and Courtiers— now good boy, good Sinior, a paire of massie siluer Spurs, to a hatch short sword, and then your imbroderd hanger, and good Sinior.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Shut the windowes, darken the roome, fetch whips, the fellow is madde, hee raues, hee raues, talkes idly, lunatique, who procures thy—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: One that has eate fat Capon, suckt the boild Chicken, & let out his wit with the foole of bounty, one Fabius, ile scorne him, hee goes vpon Fridaies in black satten.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Fabius, by this light, a cogging Chetor, he liues on loue of Marchants wiues, hee stands on the base, of maines, hee furnisheth your ordinary, for which he feeds scot-free, keepes faire gold in his purse, to put on vpon maines, by which he liues and keepes a faire boy at his heeles, he is dam'd Fabius.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: He is a fine man law, and has a good wit for when he list he can go in black Sattin, I and in a cloake lin'd with vnshorne Veluet.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: By the saluation of humanity he's more pestilent then the plague of Lice that fell vpon Egipt, thou hast bin knaue if thou credit it, thou art an Asse if thou follow it, & shalt be a perpetual Ideot if thou persue it, renounce the world, the flesh, the Diuell, and thy trust in mens wiues for they wil double with thee, and so I betake my selfe to the sucking of the iuice Capon, my ingle Bottle-ale, & his Gentleman vsher that squiers him red herring, a foole I found thee & a foole I leaue thee, beare record heauen tis against the prouidence of my speach, God boy good Sinior.

div.stage: Enter Slip Nows, Doite, and Bydet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, God boy good Sinior, what a foole 'tis, ha, ha, what an Asse 'tis, saue you young Gentlemen, is shee comming, will she meete me, shal's incounter ha?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You were not lapt in your Mothers smock, you ha not a good cheeke, an inticing eye, a smooth skinne, a well shapt leg, a faire hand, you cannot bring a wench into a fooles parradize for you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not I by this garter, I am a foole, a very Ninny I, how call you her? how call you her?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Call her, you rise on your right side to day marry, call her, her name is Mistresse Perpetuana, shee is not very faire, nor goes extraordinary gay.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: She has a good skinne?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: A good skin? she is wealthy, her husbands a foole, sheele make you, she weares the breeches: sheele make you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ile keepe two men and they shall be Taylors, they shall make sutes continually, and those shall be cloath of siluer.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You may go in beaten pretious Stones euery day, marry I must acquaint you with some obseruances which you must persue most religiously, she has a foole, a naturall foole waights on her, that is indeed her pander to him, at the first you must be bounteous, what-so-ere hee craues, bee it your Hatte, Cloake, Rapier, Purse, or such trifle, giu't, giu't, the night will pay all: and to draw all suspect, from persuing her loue for base gaine sake.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Giu't by this light, Ile giu't, wert, gaine, I care not for her Chaine of Pearle, onely her loue; gaine? the first thing her bounty shal fetch is my blush colour Satten sute from pawn: gaine?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: When you heare one winde a Cornet, shee is comming downe Saint Markes streete, prepare your speech, suck your lippes, lighten your spirits, fresh your bloud, sleeke your cheekes, for now thou shalt be made for euer (a perpetuall and eternall gull) Exit Bydet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I shall so rauish her with my court-ship, I haue such variety of discourse, such coppy of phrase to begin, as this; sweete Lady Vlisses Dog after his Maisters ten yeares trauell, I shall so ticle her, or thus, Pure beauty there is a stone.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Two stones man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Called, 'tis no matter what; I ha the eloquence, I am not to seeke I warrant you.
The Cornet is winded, Enter Pippo Bydet, Pippo attired like a Merchants wife, and Bydet like a Foole .Sweete Lady Vlisses dog, there's a stone called—, O Lord what shall I say.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Is all your eloquence come to this?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The glorious radient of your glimmering eies, your glittering beauties blind my witt, and dazled my—

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: Ile put on my maske and please you, pray you winke, pray you.

sp.speaker: Bidet.
sp.p: O fine man, my mistresse loues you best, I dreamt you ga me this sword and dagger, I loue your Hatte and Feather, O.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Do not crie man, do not crie man, thou shalt ha them I and they were—

sp.speaker: Bydet.
sp.p: O that purse with all the white pence in it, fine man I loue you, giue you the fine red pence soone at night, he, I thanke you where's the foole now?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: He has all my money, I haue to keepe my selfe, and—

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Poght.

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: Sir the foole shall lead you to my house, the foole shall not, at night I expect you, till then take this seale of my affection.

sp.speaker: Within Qua.
sp.p: What Simplicius.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I come Quadratus, Gentlemen as yet I can but thanke you, but I must bee trusted for my ordinary soone at night, or stay Ile— the foole has vnfurnisht mee, but 'twill come againe, good boy.

sp.speaker: Within, Qua.
sp.p: What ho Simplicius?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Good boy, good boyes, I come, I come, good boyes, good boyes.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: The foole shall waight on thee, Now do I merrit to bee yclipped Bosphoros Carmelydon Honorificacuminos Bydett, who who has any square Dice?

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: Marry Sir that haue I.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Thou shalt loose thy share for it in our purchase.

sp.speaker: Pippo.
sp.p: I pray you now, pray you now.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.l: Sooner the whissell of a Marriner,
Shall sleeke the rough curbes of the Ocean back,
Now speake I like my selfe thou shalt loose thy share.

div.stage: Enter Quadratus, Lauerdure and Celia, Simplicius Meletza, Lyzabetta Lucea and Lampatho.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Ha take all then, ha.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Without cloake or hat or rapier sigh,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gods me, looke yonder, who gaue you these things?

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: Mistris Perpetuanos foole.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mistris Perpetuanos foole, ha, ha, there lies a iest, Sinior the foole promised me he would not leaue me.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: I know the foole well, he will sticke to you, dos not vse to for-sake any youth that is inamord on an other mans wife, hee striues to keepe company with a crimson satten sute continually, he loues to be al one with a Critique, a good wit selfe conceited, a hauke bearer, a dogge keeper, and great with the nobility, hee doates vpon a meere scholler an honest flat foole, but aboue all hee is all one with a fellow whose cloake hath a better inside then his out-side, and his body richer lin'd then his braine.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Vds so I am cosoned.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Pray you maister pardon me, I must loose my share.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Giue me my purse againe.

sp.speaker: Byd.
sp.p: You gaue it me and Ile keept.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Well done my honest crack thou shalt be my ingle fort.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He shall keepe all maugre thy beardles chin thy eyes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I may go starue till Midsomer quarter.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Foole get thee hence,

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Ile to schoole againe that I will, I left in Asse in presenti, and Ile begin in Asse in presenti and so good night faire gentry.

div.stage: Exit Pippo.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: The triple Ideotts coxcombe crownes thee,
Bitter epigrames confound thee.
Cucold be when ere thou bride thee,
Through euery comick sceane be drawne,
Neuer come thy cloathes from pawne.
Neuer may thy shame be sheathed,
Neuer kisse a wench sweet breathed.

div.stage: Cornets sound.
Enter as many Pages with Torches as you can, Randolfo and Adrian, Iacomo bare, the Duke with attendantes.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Seace the Duke approacheth tis almost night,
For the Dukes vp, now begins his day
Come grace his entrance; lightes lightes now ginnes our play.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Still these same bauling pipes, sound softer straines
Slumber our scence, tut these are vulger straines,
Cannot your trembling wiers throw a chaine
Of powerfull rapture bout our mazed scence
Why is our chaire thus cushion'd tapistry
Why is our bed tired with wanton sportes?
Why are we cloath'd in glistring attiers,
If common bloudes can heare, can, feele,
Can sit as soft, lie as lasciuious
Stut all as rich as the greatest Potentate,
Soule, and you cannot feast my thristing eares
With aught but what the lip of common berth can tast,
Take all away your labors idly wast
What sport for night.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: A Commedy, intitled Temperance.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What sot elects that subiect for the Court,
What should dame Temperance do heere, away,
The itch on Temperance your morrall play.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Duke, Prince, royall bloud, thou that hast the best meanes to be damn'd of any Lord in Venice, thou great man, let me kisse thy flesh, I am fat and therefore faithfull, I will do that which few of thy subiects do; loue thee, but I will neuer do, that which all thy subiects do; flatter thee, thy humors reall, good, a Commedie?
sp.l: No and thy scence would banquit in delightes,
Appropriat to the bloud of Emperors;
Peculier to the state of Maiesty,
That none can rellish but dilated greatnesse.
Vouchafe to vew the structure of a sceane
That stands on tragike sollid passion,
O thats fit trafick to commerce with birthes:
Straind from the mud of base unable braines,
Giue them a sceane may force their struggling bloud
Rise vp on tiptoe in attention,
And fill their intellect with pure elixed wit,
O thats for greatnesse apt, for Princes fit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Darst thou then vndertake to sute our eares,
With such rich vestment.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Dare; yes my Prince I dare, nay more, I will,
And Ile present a subiect worth thy soule:
The honor'd end of Cato Vtican.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: whole personate him.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Marry that wil I on suddaine without change.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Thou want'st a beard.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Tush a beard nere made Cato, though many mens Cato hang onely on their chin.
sp.l: Suppose this flowre the City vtica,
The time the night that prolong'd Catos death:
Now being plac'd moung his Philosophers,
These first discourse the soules eternity.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Cato grantes that I am sure, for he was valiant, and honest, which an Epicure nere was, and a coward neuer will be.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Then Cato holdes a distinct notion,
Of indiuiduall actions after death:
This being argu'd his resolue maintaines,
A true magnanimous spirit should giue vp durt
To durt, and with his owne flesh dead his flesh,
Fore chance should force it crouch vnto his foe:
To kill ones selfe some I, some hold it no,
O these are pointes would intice away ones soule:
To breakes indenture of base prentisage, Enter Francisco.
And run away from's boddy in swift thoughts
To melt in contemplation lushious sweetes,
Now my voluptious Duke ile feede thy scence,
Worth his creation: giue me audience.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My leidge my royall leidge, heare, heare my sute.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Now may thy breath nere smell sweete as long as thy loungs can pant for breaking my speech, thou Muscouite, thou stinking perfumer.

div.stage: Enter Albano.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Is not this Albano our some times Courtier?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No troth but Francisco your alwaies perfumer.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Lorenzo Celso our braue Venice Duke, Albano Belletzo, thy Merchant, thy soldier, thy Courtier, thy slaue, thy any-thing, thy What thou wilt, kisseth thy noble bloud, doe mee right or els I am canonized a cuckold, canonized a cuckold, I am abus'd, I am abusd, my wifes abusd, my cloathes abusd, my shape, my house my all abusd, I am sworne out of my selfe, beated out of my selfe baffled, geird at, laught at, bard my owne house, debard my owne wife, whilst others swill my wines, gurmandize my meat, meat, kisse my wife, O gods, O gods, O gods, O gods, O gods.

sp.speaker: Lauer.
sp.p: Who ist? who ist?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come sweete this is your waggery yfaith, as if you knew him not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes I feare I do too wel, would I could slide away invisible.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Assured this is hee.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: My worthy leidge the iest comes only thus.
Now to stop and crosse it with mere like deceite:
All being knowne the French knight hath disguisd,
A fiddler like Albano too, to fright the perfumer, this is all.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Art sure tis true.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: Tis confest tis right.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: It is right, tis true, right, I am a fiddler, a fiddler, a fidler vds fut a fidler; Ile not beleeue thee thou art a woman, and tis knowne veritas non querit angulos, truth seekes not to lurke vnder varthingalls, veritas non querit angulos, a fidler?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Worthy sir pardon, and permit me first to confesse your selfe, your deputation dead hath made my loue liue, to offend you.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: I, mock on, skoffe on, flout on, do do do.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Troth sir in serious.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: I good, good, come hether Celia,
Burst breast, riue heart a sunder? Celia
Why startest thou back: seest thou this Celia
O me how often with lasciuious touch thy lip,
Hath kissd this mark? how oft this much wrong'd breast
Hath borne the gentle waight of thy soft cheeke?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: O me my deerest Lord, my sweete, sweete loue.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: What a fidler, a fidler? now thy loue.
I am sure thou skornst; it nay Celia, I could tell
What on the night before I went to sea,
And tooke my leaue with Hymeneall rights
What, thou lispsd
Into my eare, a fidler and perfumer now.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: And—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Deere brother.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.l: Most respected Sinior,
Beleeue it by the sacred end of loue,
What much, much wronge hath forc'd your patience
Proceeded from most deere affied loue,
Deuoted to your house.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.p: Beleeue it brother.

sp.speaker: Iaco.
sp.p: Nay your selfe when you shall heare the occurrances will say tis happy, commicall.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Assure thee brother.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Shall I be braue, shall I be my selfe now, loue, giue me thy loue, brothers giue me your breasts, French knight reach me thy hand, perfumer thy fist. Duke I inuite thee, loue I forgiue thee: Frenchman I hug thee, Ile know all, ile pardon all, and Ile laugh at all.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: And ile curse you all.
O yee ha interrupt a sceane.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Quadratus we will heare these pointes discussd,
With apter and more calme affected houres.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Well, good, good.

sp.speaker: Alba
sp.l: Wast euen so yfaith why then caprichious mirth,
Skip light moriscoes in our frolick bloud,
Flaggd veines, sweete, plump with fresh infused ioyes:
Laughter pucker our cheekes, make shoulders shog,
With chucking lightnesse, loue once more thy lippes,
For euer claspe our hands, our hearts, our Creasts,
Thus front, thus eyes, thus cheeke, thus all shall meete.
Shall clip, shall hug, shall kisse, my deere, deere sweete,
Duke wilt thou see me reuell, come loue daunce,
Court gallants court; suck amorous dalliance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Beauty your heart.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.l: First sir accept my hands.
Shee leapes too rash, that falls in suddeine bands.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Shall I dispaire? neuer will I loue more.

sp.speaker: Melet.
sp.p: No sea so boundles vast but hath a shore.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Why marry me.
Thou canst haue but soft flesh, good bloud, sound bones.
And that which fils vp all your bracks, good stones.

sp.speaker: Lyzabet.
sp.l: Stones, Trees and beasts in loue still firmer prooue,
Then man, Ile none no hold-fastes in your loues.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Since not the Mistresse, come on Faith the maide:

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.p: Ten thousand Duckets too to bote are laide.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why then winde Cornets, lead on iolly ladde.

sp.speaker: Alla.
sp.l: Excuse me gallants though my legges lead wrong.
'Tis my first footing, winde out nimble tongue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis well, 'tis well, how shall we spend this night?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Gulpe Rhenish Wine my liedge, let our paunch rent,
Suck merry Gellyes, preuiew but not preuent
No mortall can the miseries of life.

sp.speaker: Alba.
sp.l: I home inuite you all, come sweete, sweete wife,
My liedge vouchsafe thy presence, drinke till the ground looke blew, boy.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Liue still springing hopes, still in fresh new ioyes,
May your loues happy hit in faire cheekt wiues,
Your flesh still plumpe with sap'd restoratiues,
That's all my honest frolick heart can wish,
A Fico for the mew and Enuious pish,
Till night, I wish good food and pleasing day,
sp.p: But then found rest so ends or slight writ play. Exeunt.

div.stage: Deo op: max gratias.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
